root: ^Yes, I thought it right to deliver some cham-cham that I got to you. In respects to your sons passing and to thank you.
^Nolwazi gives the Cham-cham for his son-in-law’s passing
^You have already given me so much
^He accepts the bottle in his shaking hands and begins to lament, recalling the memories of that unfortunate time.

^You know, my daughter hasn’t been herself since that day. Th eone thing that brought her joy was to stare at the wall in the middle of the village and was interested in all the different names and masks on the wall, but ever since the officials showed up, the masks were shaken off and his people kept their own for safe keeping.
^What was the significance of this wall? .
^Oh It was a family tree and putting it back together would really reconnect everyone.
^A sudden realization dawns on Nolwazi as she hears Baboto's tale.
^I see. You know this mask belonged to my Grandmother, the woman in the photograph. If what you say is true then evryone here is my family too..
^Oh my that is wonderful. I would have you know that the wall being mistreated would have brought her great displeasure if she was anything like us.
^I know. That is why I will do what I can to restore the tree and our families heritage. You can count on me Elder. .

^You are so brave. You must continue to be this strong. The world you come from is cruel and the journey you take against it is dangerous. Here take my own mask, put them all back together. I wish you well.
